ocr.sentence: matter the king was very glad hereof, and caused the combatants to be brought before him, to whom he said gentlemen, to save the blood of you all, I have found a way, and yet the controversie shall be ended that is now amongst you Are you contented to stand to his iudg-ment that I shall appoint they all answered, that they were.
ocr.region: OF FRYER BACON. 221 the matter the kingwas very glad hereof,and caused the combatants to be brought before him, to whom he said gentlemen, to save the blood of you all, I have found a way, and yet the controversie shall be ended that is now amongst you Are you contented to stand to his iudg ment that I shaU appoint they all answered, that they were. Then were they bid to returne three days after. In that time Fryer Bacon had caused the body of their deceased father to be taken out of the ground, and brought to the court the body hee did cause to be bound to a stake, naked to the middle upwards and Hkewise prepared three bowes and shafts for the three brethren all these kept hee secretly. The third day being come, came these three brethren, to whom Fryer Bacon in the presence of the king gave the three bowes and shafts, saying, be not offended at what I have done, there is no other way but this to judge your cause See here is the body of your dead father, shoot at him, for he that cometh nearest to his heart, shad have aU the lands and goods. The two eldest prepared themselves, and shot at him, and stucke their arrowes in his breast. Then bid they the youngest to shoot but he refused it, saying, I will rather loose aU, then wound that body that I so loved living Had you ever had but halfe that love in you to him that I have, you would rather have had your own bodies mangled, than to suffer his lifelesse corps thus to be used nay, you doe not onely suffer it, but you are the actors of this act of shame and speaking this, he wept.

The third day being come, came these three brethren, to whom Fryer Bacon in the presence of the king gave the three bowes and shafts, saying, be not offended at what I have done, there is no other way but this to judge your cause See here is the body of your dead father, shoot at him, for he that cometh nearest to his heart, shad have aU the lands and goods. The two eldest prepared themselves, and shot at him, and stucke their arrowes in his breast. Then bid they the youngest to shoot but he refused it, saying, I will rather loose aU, then wound that body that I so loved living Had you ever had but halfe that love in you to him that I have, you would rather have had your own bodies mangled, than to suffer his lifelesse corps thus to be used nay, you doe not onely suffer it, but you are the actors of this act of shame and speaking this, he wept.

ocr.sentence: his master had great marvaile then they sate downe to breakfast, which being ended they went home, and did such thinges as were there to bee done when his dame sawe that he had so soone ended his busines, she thought that he was a profitable servant, and said little but let him alone.
ocr.region: OF FRIER RUSH. 295 whereat his master had great marvade then they sate downe to breakfast, which being ended they went home, and did such thinges as were there to bee done when his dame sawe that he had so soone ended his busines, she thought that he was a profitable servant, and said Httle but let him alone. In the evening Rush de maunded of his master what hee should doe the next morrow ? his master appointed him twice so much as hee did the day before, which Rush refused not, but got up earely in the morning, and went to the field, and about his worke so soone as his master was ready, he tooke his man's breakfast and came to the field, thinking to helpe Rush but he was no sooner come from his house but the Priest came to see his wife, and presently shee made ready some good meate for them to be merry withall, and whyle it was a dressing, they sate sporting together, who had beene there should have seene many loving touches. And when the goodman came to the field, he found that Rush had done aU that which he appointed, whereof he had great marvade then they sate dovroe to breakfast, and as they sate together, Rush beheld his master's shoone, and perceived that for fault of greasing they were very hard then said Rush to his master, why are not your shooes better greased ? I marvade that you can goe in them, they be so hard, have you no more at home ? Ves, said his master, I have another payre lying under a great chest at home in my chamber. Then said Rush I wdl goe home and grease them that you may put them on to-morrow and

In the evening Rush de maunded of his master what hee should doe the next morrow ? his master appointed him twice so much as hee did the day before, which Rush refused not, but got up earely in the morning, and went to the field, and about his worke so soone as his master was ready, he tooke his man's breakfast and came to the field, thinking to helpe Rush but he was no sooner come from his house but the Priest came to see his wife, and presently shee made ready some good meate for them to be merry withall, and whyle it was a dressing, they sate sporting together, who had beene there should have seene many loving touches. And when the goodman came to the field, he found that Rush had done aU that which he appointed, whereof he had great marvade then they sate dovroe to breakfast, and as they sate together, Rush beheld his master's shoone, and perceived that for fault of greasing they were very hard then said Rush to his master, why are not your shooes better greased ? I marvade that you can goe in them, they be so hard, have you no more at home ? Ves, said his master, I have another payre lying under a great chest at home in my chamber. Then said Rush I wdl goe home and grease them that you may put them on to-morrow and

ocr.sentence: space of seaven yeares, and did right well, and every man had him in love and favour.
ocr.region: OF FRIER RUSH. 271 the space of seaven yeares, and did right well, and every man bad him in love and favour. Then it fortuned upon a day the Priour and his brethren were assembled together in a generaU counsaile, and as they stood talking together, the Priour remembered Rush, and anon he said unto his brethren Friends we have here Rush which is our maister Cooke in our kitchin, and be is an olde servant, and much diligent and true service he hath done to us, and he hath continued among us longer then any servant that ever wee had wherefore me thinke it reason, that hee were promoted into some other office, and made a brother among us. Then all the whole Covent with one voice said they were content it should so be. So the Priour sent for Rush, and when he was come before him and aU bis brethren, the Priour said, Rush it is so, thou hast beene here a long season, and we have found thee hitherto a true and diligent servant, wherefore wee wdl that thou be promoted, and take upon thee an habite as we have, and to become a brother among us. Rush answered and said my Maisters I thanke you aU, and then the Priour gave Rush an habite, and put it on his backe, and so Rush became a brother in the place, neverthelesse he kept his office stiU. How Frier Rush made Truncheons for the Friers to fight withaU. When Rush had on the habite of a Frier, and was a brother in the place, he had more vacation dayes

ocr.sentence: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE.
ocr.region: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. 251 comme une exception parmi le commun des hommes, et que vous tiez ce qu'ils sont tous, perfides et trompeurs  l'occasion. Quand je relevai la tte, l'obscurit la plus complte salait faite dans votre logement, et une lueur d'espoir tra-, versa mon esprit. Point de doute vous alliez venir, vous alliez paratre. Nulle puissance humaine ne m'et contrainte  croire que vous passeriez la journe sans me voir et sans tenir la promesse que vous m'aviez faite. Vous tiez-donc en. chemin j'en tais convaincue comme d'un article de foi. En - effet, la sonnette retentit quelqu'un tait l. - Ab 1 enfin, m'criai-je, le voici Dieu soit lou ! Je courus vers la porte et ouvris. C'tait Melchior. XXVI Je ne chercherai pas, Ludovic,  vous raconter ce que j'prouvai  la vue de cet homme. Ce fut un sentiment si bizarre, si ml, si excessif qu'il me serait impossible de l'analyser. Ce qui y dominait, c'tait la colre vis--vis de vous, et vis--vis de lui de la rpugnance. Pourquoi tait-il l et non pas vous? A quel titre se prsentait-il 1 Etait-ce de votre part? Que pouvait-il avoir  me dire? A -tout. prendre, si c'tait votre messager, vous aviez eu, en le choisissant, la main singulirement malheureuse. Il faut que ma physionomie ait exprim, en partie du moins, les sentiments qui m'agitaient, ou bien que Melchior et prpar, en habile acteur, les nuances de son rle. Tou-jours est-il qu'il s'en tira  son avantage et se conduisit de manire  me dsarmer. Dans l'opinion que je m'en tais forme, cet homme devait porter en tout lieu et en toute cir-constance les airs impertinents qui lui taient habituels et dont j'avais eu tant  souffrir. Je me figurais qu'il allait le prendre sur le mme pied et se mettre  l'aise chez moi comme il s'y

Nulle puissance humaine ne m'et contrainte  croire que vous passeriez la journe sans me voir et sans tenir la promesse que vous m'aviez faite. Vous tiez donc en chemin j'en tais convaincue comme d'un article de foi. En effet, la sonnette retentit quelqu'un tait l. -Ah ! enfin, m'criai-je, le voici Dieu soit lou ! Je courus vers la porte et ouvris. C'tait Melchior. XXVI Je ne chercherai pas, Ludovic,  vous raconter ce que j'prouvai  la vue de cet homme. Ce fut un sentiment si bizarre, si ml, si excessif qu'il me serait impossible de l'analyser. Ce qui y dominait, c'tait la colre vis--vis de vous, et vis--vis de lui de la rpugnance. Pourquoi tait-il l et non pas vous ? A quel titre se prsentait-il ! tait-ce de votre part ? Que pouvait-il avoir  me dire ? A tout prendre, si c'tait votre messager, vous aviez eu, en le choisissant, la main singulirement malheureuse. Il faut que ma physionomie ait exprim, en partie du moins, les sentiments qui m'agitaient, ou bien que Melchior et prpar, en habile acteur, les nuances de son rle. Tou-jours est-il qu'il s'en tira  son avantage et se conduisit de manire  me dsarmer. Dans l'opinion que je m'en tais forme, cet homme devait porter en tout lieu et en toute cir-constance les airs impertinents qui lui taient habituels et dont j'avais eu tant  souffrir. Je me figurais qu'il allait le prendre sur le mme pied et se mettre  l'aise chez moi comme il s'y

Elle s'excusait d'avoir si peu  offrir, et priait qu'on lui tint compte de l'intention saps s'arrter  la valeur des choses. Chaque legs tait d'ailleurs appropri  la personne avec un soin dlicat qui y ajoutait un nouveau prix. Marguerite eut une dernire attention elle laissa son se-crtaire ouvert et plaa sur la tablette la pice qui rendait Ludovic matre de tout rgler chez elle et d'agir  son gr. Prs du testament tait l'anneau, ce triste et mystrieux em-blme. Ds le premier abord les yeux devaient se porter sur ces objets, et le jeune homme y reconnatrait quelles avaient t, au moment de quitter ce monde, la pense de la mou-rante et sa proccupation. Quand elle en eut fini avec la terre, Marguerite songea au ciel elle s'agenouilla devant le portrait de sa grand'mre et pria avec ferveur. Que fut cette prire? Sans doute un acte de contritipp et en mme temps un cri de dsespoir. Elle prit Dieu  tmoin, et, lui montrant l'tat de son me, invo-qua sa misricorde ayec un accent plor. Puis s'adressant  cette aeule qui avait si saintement vcu et si saintement fini,  sa mre moissonne avant le temps et qui, son mari mort, avait, elle aussi, manqu de courage, elle les conjura sans doute d'intercder pour elle et d'obtenir qu'elle ft admise  leurs cts, daps le sjour des mes pures ou purifies par le repentir. Elle leur demanda d'unir leurs prires  la sienne afin d'en augmenter l'effet et d'ob-tenir ce pardon qui descend d'en haut sur les coeurs humi-lis et sincres. Quand elle eut mis sa conscience en paix, autant que le permettait l'acte violent auquel elle tait rsolue, elle monta sur son lit, ajusta ses vtements de manire  ce que rien n'y pt amener du dsordre, s'tendit sur les coussins, et, s'emparant d'une petite fiole qui tait  sa porte, elle l'ap-procha de ses lvres. 1 Quelques minutes aprs , elle tait plonge dans un en-gourdissement profond.

ocr.sentence: the other young man, this his father had received wrong.
ocr.region: 247 OF FRYER BACON. told the other young man, this his father had received wrong. He answered againe, that it was faire. At last there grew such foule words betweenc them, and their bloods were so heated, that they presently stabbed one the other with their daggers, and so fell downe dead. Fryer Bacon seeing them fall, ranne to them, but it was too late, for they were breathlesse ere he came. This made him to grieve exceedingly be iudging that they had received the cause of their deaths by this glasse, tooke the glasse in his hand, aud uttered words to this effect Wretched Bacon, wretched in thy knowledge, in thy understanding wretched for thy art hath beene the ruine of these two gentlemen. Had I been busied in those holy things, the which mine order tyes me to, I had not had that time that made this wicked glasse wicked I weU may cad it, that is the causer of so vde an act would it were sensible, then should it feele my wrath but being as it is, He ruin it for ruining of them and with that he broke his rare and wonderftdl glasse, whose Hke the whole world had not. In this grief of his, came there newes to him of the deaths of Vandermast and Fryer Bungey This did increase his griefe, and made him sorrowfull, that in three days he would not eate any thing but kept his chamber.

At last there grew such foule words betweene them, and their bloods were so heated, that they presently stabbed one the other with their daggers, and so fell downe dead. Fryer Bacon seeing them fall, ranne to them, but it was too late, for they were breathlesse ere he came. This made him to grieve exceedingly he iudging that they had received the cause of their deaths by this glasse, tooke the glasse in his hand, and uttered words to this effect Wretched Bacon, wretched in thy knowledge, in thy understanding wretched for thy art hath beene the ruine of these two gentlemen. Had I been busied in those holy things, the which mine order tyes me to, I had not had that time that made this wicked glasse wicked I well may call it, that is the causer of so vile an act would it were sensible, then should it feele my wrath but being as it is, Ile ruin it for ruining of them and with that he broke his rare and wonderfull glasse, whose like the whole world had not. In this grief of his, came there newes to him of the deaths of Vandermast and Fryer Bungey This did increase his griefe, and made him sorrowfull, that in three days he would not eate any thing but kept his chamber.

ocr.sentence: debate and strife to fall betweene man and wife, and caused the wife to cut her husband's throat that was well done said the master, thou shalt be well re-warded for thy labour.
ocr.region: 286 A PLEASANT HISTORIE caused debate and strife to fall betweene man and wife, and caused the wife to cut her husband's throat that was weU done said the master, thou shalt be well re-warded for thy labour. Then foorth came another Devill named Downesnest, and said, Sir, I have caused two olde women to fight so sore together, and to beat each other about the head, that their eyes flew out that was well done said the master DeviU, with much thanke thou shalt be weU rewarded for thy labour. Then foorth went Frier Rush freshly, and with a good courage, and said Sir, I am in a religious place, and I governe the priour and his covent as I wiU myselfe, and they have me in great love and favour for I doe them many great pleasures, and I have brought them faire wenches every man one when they lust, and divers times I have caused debate and strife to faU among them, and I have made them staves, and caused them to fight stifly together, and to breake each others heads, and their armes and legges, and yet wiU I doe more among them ere I depart out of the place, for I shall make so great debate and strife among them, and the one shaU flea the other, then they sbaU come and dweU with us in hell, and burne in perpetuaU fire without end. Then said the maister Devdl to Rush, if thou have done as thou hast said, thou hast done well thy part, and I pray thee be ddigent thy selfe about thy businesse, and stirre them to sin, and speciaUy to these three, that is to say, wrath, gluttony, and lechery, and briefely to make an end of thy enterprise, and slip it not and

ocr.sentence: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE.
ocr.region: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. 269 o cette scne se passait. Par le concours des circonstances, j'tais compromise  un point qu'aucune rparation n'tait possible, si ce n'est celle que pouvait m'offrir Melcbior. Son but tait atteint il m'avait mise  la discrtion de son hon-neur. Triste garantie ! et je le vis bien plus tard. Je succombai une barrire s'leva entre vous et moi je ne pouvais plus tre  vous, Ludovic. Les heures s'cou-laient il fallut prendre un parti. Encore quelques instants, et vous alliez venir chercher votre fiance impossible de vous attendre en vous voyant je serais tombe morte  vos pieds. Nous primes donc, Melchior et moi, nos dernires dis-positions. Au petit jour, et quand la porte fut ouverte, il quitta la maison. Un rendez-vous avait t fix, et je devais aller le rejoindre. Il passa sans tre aperu peut-tre le concierge tait-il son complice. Quant  moi, je restai pendant une heure encore abme dans mes regrets et mes remords. -Toutes vos bonts me revinrent alors  la mmoire, et je me trouvai bien ingrate, bien cruelle et en mme temps bien dchue. -Qu'ai liez-vous penser de moi? Hlas 1 quoi que vous pussiez en penser, la ralit dpasserait vos suppositions. J'tais une fille dshonore ! XXX - Pourtant, Ludovic, je vous crivis quelques mots, non pas tels que j'aurais voulu les crire, mais assez prcis pour que dsormais vous me regardassiez comme perdue pour vous. Puis j'enlevai de mon doigt l'anneau qui me venait de ma grand'mre et qui avait si mal prserv mon honneur. Je n'tais plus digne de le porter, quoi qu'il arrivt et de quel-que faon que tournassent les choses. Je rejoignis Melchior et le trouvai ivre de son bonheur. Moi-mme,  ce premier moment, j'prouvai ce vertige des sens qui n'est que la fausse monnaie de l'amour. Melchior

prediction.region: Incorrect text: In the street where this scene was passing, I was compromised at a point where no repair could be done, if not the one that could have offered me Melior. His aim was accomplished. He had made me a hostage of his honor. His purpose was reached. He had put me at the disposal of his shame. To be broken down at his feet is the worst humiliation a man can be subjected to, and I was crushed by it. - To be so cruelly cut off at the moment I was longing to be by your side, Ludovic. The days passed, and we had to make a choice between opposing our wishes, and losing each other in the storm of events. Yet still more unfortunate was it that we should come to an agreement, and then be severed by one who might have been the true friend of our hearts, and the preserver of our honor, rather than the one we had to deal with. At last we had to give in to fate. And when the door was opened, Melchior left the house. A rendezvous had been fixed for us, and I must go to meet him. He had passed without being noticed by anybody, for the house-keeper was perhaps his accomplice. As for me, I remained for an hour longer buried in my grief and regrets, while Melchior was rejoicing in his happiness. - Then, Ludovic, the remembrance of all your kindness returned to me then and there, and I found myself quite ungrateful, quite cruel and very dejected. - What have you thought of me? Alas, alas! your worst expectations were fulfilled. I was a girl disgraced! XXX</s>

prediction.region: Incorrect text: In the street where this scene was passing, I was compromised at a point where no repair could be done, if not the one that could have offered me Melior. Alas, alas! your worst expectations were fulfilled. I was a girl disgraced! XXX</s>

ocr.sentence: Encore quelques instants, et vous alliez venir chercher votre fiance impossible de vous attendre en vous voyant je serais tombe morte  vos pieds.
ocr.region: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. 269 o cette scne se passait. Par le concours des circonstances, j'tais compromise  un point qu'aucune rparation n'tait possible, si ce n'est celle que pouvait m'offrir Melcbior. Son but tait atteint il m'avait mise  la discrtion de son hon-neur. Triste garantie ! et je le vis bien plus tard. Je succombai une barrire s'leva entre vous et moi je ne pouvais plus tre  vous, Ludovic. Les heures s'cou-laient il fallut prendre un parti. Encore quelques instants, et vous alliez venir chercher votre fiance impossible de vous attendre en vous voyant je serais tombe morte  vos pieds. Nous primes donc, Melchior et moi, nos dernires dis-positions. Au petit jour, et quand la porte fut ouverte, il quitta la maison. Un rendez-vous avait t fix, et je devais aller le rejoindre. Il passa sans tre aperu peut-tre le concierge tait-il son complice. Quant  moi, je restai pendant une heure encore abme dans mes regrets et mes remords. -Toutes vos bonts me revinrent alors  la mmoire, et je me trouvai bien ingrate, bien cruelle et en mme temps bien dchue. -Qu'ai liez-vous penser de moi? Hlas 1 quoi que vous pussiez en penser, la ralit dpasserait vos suppositions. J'tais une fille dshonore ! XXX - Pourtant, Ludovic, je vous crivis quelques mots, non pas tels que j'aurais voulu les crire, mais assez prcis pour que dsormais vous me regardassiez comme perdue pour vous. Puis j'enlevai de mon doigt l'anneau qui me venait de ma grand'mre et qui avait si mal prserv mon honneur. Moi-mme,  ce premier moment, j'prouvai ce vertige des sens qui n'est que la fausse monnaie de l'amour. Melchior

Quant  moi, je restai pendant une heure encore abme dans mes regrets et mes remords. -Toutes vos bonts me revinrent alors  la mmoire, et je me trouvai bien ingrate, bien cruelle et en mme temps bien dchue. -Qu'ai liez-vous penser de moi? Hlas 1 quoi que vous pussiez en penser, la ralit dpasserait vos suppositions. J'tais une fille dshonore ! ocr.sentence: 278 CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE.
ocr.region: 278 CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. - Plus vite ce serait difficile nous marchons  en perdre la respiration. - Avez-vous au moins tout ce qu'il vous faut en cas d'-vnement? - Soyez tranquille - Des antidotes surtout? - Ne vous en proccupez pas j'y ai song d'ailleurs c'est de rgle aujourd'hui. Tout mdecin a sur lui sa petite pharmacie. Ils touchaient  la porte de Marguerite. Ludovic passa r-solment et enjamba les degrs sans mme jeter un nom au concierge. Mal lui en prit. On sait  quel homme il avait af-faire, c'tait un casuiste en matire d'attributions il s'lana  la poursuite de l'intrus. - Monsieurl s'cria-t-il, Monsieur! Ludovic tait dj loin. Mais le docteur y avait mis moins de zle, et ce fut sur lui que le concierge se rabattit. - O allez-vous, Monsieur? lui dit-il en lui barrant le pas-sage. Le docteur et t embarrass de le dire. Il avait suivi son ami et ignorait ehez qui ils allaient. - O je vais? dit-il avec un peu d'impatience mais vous le voyez bien. - Comment, je le vois? mais je vois que vous tombez sur mon escalier comme une bombe sans me dire seulement gare, ni me fournir un mot d'explication. Voil ce que je vois. - J'accompagne mon camarade, dit le docteur en essayant de s'ouvrir un chemin laissez-moi passer. - Votre camarade? Il est aussi peu gn que vous 1 - Voyons, finissons-en. La querelle s'chauffait, et l'austre concierge tait bien dcid  faire respecter ses consignes, dtlt-il compromettre l'intgrit de ses membres. Il avait pris la rampe  deux mains et s'arc-boutait de manire  ce qu'il ne restt point d'espace libre sur les degrs. A moins de violence, le pas-sage tait infranchissable, et le docteur n'osait pas pousser les choses si loin. Heureusement Ludovic se ravisa sans lui, l'affaire ne pouvait pas s'arranger il prit le parti de des-cendre.

prediction.region:
In the hope of obtaining freedom, in 1790, to choose for their representatives to the National Assembly, the priests who had already proved themselves independent of their superiors, and who possessed the talent of the word, declared that the future was frightful, and, as a consequence, an extraordinary energy was lent to his voice; he proclaimed openly the horrors, the sacrileges, and finally the massacres, which he foresaw, predicted, and in the end became himself the first victim. Yes, said he often, we shall see the blood of priests running from the Church.. However, the leaders of the National Assembly followed their destructive plan, by breaking up all the monasteries, and proclaiming the alleged constitution of civil clergy, on January 22, 1790. ocr.sentence: LES TLPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 9 III LA FERME DE BEAUSJOUR L A feuille  la main, le sergent, debout devant l'abri du colonel, faisait la rpartition des postes.
ocr.region: LES TLPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 9 III LA FERME DE BEAUSJOUR L A feuille  la main, le sergent, debout devant l'abri du colonel, faisait la rpartition des postes. - Duruy, dit-il, tu vas monter avec tes hommes au secteur I, tu longeras un peu la route jusqu'aux boyaux B 1 et B 2, au tournant du ruisseau, ils sont perpendiculaires  la Grande Transversale, aprs quoi tu monteras tout droit jus-qu'au poste du commandant. Ne t'amuse pas en chemin, car  peu prs cinq cents mtres avant d'arriver, il voltige des bom-bes!. Legrand, tu prends le secteur H, dangereux pour les marmites, surtout au Bois Equerre tu suivras le boyau central jusqu'au boyau Boscary, o tu trouveras le poste de son com-mandant. Attention vous autres, baissez la tte, les balles tra-versent la route! Je garde deux hommes avec moi au poste du colonel,  da borne 16. La nuit tait venne, pas de lune, une obscurit complte rgnait sur les tranches, et sauf les coups de fusils espacs, partant des premires lignes, la soire tait calme. Les fuses dans le ciel irradiaient par moments l'horizon de leur courbe gracieuse, inondant les parapets d'une lueur blafarde. L'quipe se spara en deux. Puis,  la file, les nouveaux venus longrent la route le plus prs possible du remblai pour viter les balles perdues qui froufroutaient avec un bruit de soie, allant frapper les troncs d'arbres de l'autre ct du ruis-seau. - Pour une belle nuit, c'est une beMe nuit, remarqua R-gnier, un combat de ngres sous un tunnel et  chaque fuse il gouaillait Ah! la belle bleue! - Allez, activez le mouvement, lana Legrand impatient, en laissant derrire lui Duruy qui entrait dans son boyau, nous avons encore un bout de chemin! Sans se dtourner il poursuivit sa marche  ttons, cher-chant  ehaque trou la pancarte indicatrice.

The shots in the sky scattered their light by moments with a graceful grace. The battery guns fired one after another, filling the horizon with a blaze of graceful radiance. The team separated into two. Then, at the file, the new recruits went the route nearest the trees to avoid the fallen shells which splattered against the trunks on the other side of the river. Then he continued his march by treading lightly, in search to find the signboard to indicate the battalion. He didn't take a diversion to find the signal, as it is necessary to arrive five hundred meters from the post before turning it. Oh, the beautiful blue! - Come on, let's go move up the movement, ordered Legrand impatiently, leaving Duruy, who entered his boyau, behind him. We still have one more leg of the course! Don't turn around, let's go on! Without turning around, he pressed on his way, impatiently waiting for the battalion to pass. He didn't turn back, he pressed on, with his head looking around, for the signboard indicating the battalion's post. ocr.sentence: CE PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE.
ocr.region: CE qu'on PEUT VOIR DANS UNE rue. 257, j'obis, tant il y avait en moi de confusion et de trouble. Il faut si. peu de chose pour arrter une confidence sur les lvres, surtout lorsqu'il s'agit de s'accuser d'un tort et de se mettre  la merci d'autrui ! On s'empare alors du premier prtexte, le plus futile, le plus spcieux on recule, on ajourne, et, dans ces ajournements mmes, -on puise des mo-tifs pour s'abstenir. C'est ce qui m'arriva, Ludovic. Avant- de vous revoir, j'tais rsolue  tout vous dire, et quand je vous revis la confiance me manqua. Il n'y eut l-dedans ni raisonnement, ni calcul mais une force imprieuse et presque indpen-dante de ma volont. Puis je me payais de dfaites. Pourquoi troubler votre scurit et veiller vos soupons? La chose en valait-elle la peine? Cet homme, en venant chez moi, avait obi  un caprice probablement il n'y reviendrait plus. Et s'il revenait, quoi de plus ais que de le remettre  sa place et de faire justice de ses airs cavaliers ? tait-il besoin d'aide pour cela et ne valait-il pas mieux procder sans bruit, sans clat, .comme une femme peut et doit le faire, que de mettre deux hommes en prsence et jusqu'aux prises pour un si lger motif? Voil  quelles impressions je cdai sans m'en rendre bien compte, ni pntrer trop avant dans mon coeur Peut-tre, hlas ! en interrogeant mieux ce coeur, aurais-je trouv le dernier mot de ces rticences. La suite ne l'a que trop prouv j'tais dj touche, j'entrais dans cette srie de faiblesses qui m'ont perdue. C'est ici que j'ai besoin de votre pardon, Ludovic, d'un pardon absolu et gnreux. Point d'excuse possible, rien qui puisse pallier ce commen-cement de trahison. Vous aviez t pour moi le meilleur, le plus dvou et le plus fidle des amis vous n'aviez qu'une pense, mon bonheur qu'un but, notre union. Jamais, c'est une justice que je me plais  vous rendre, aucun chagrin ne m'est venu de vous si j'exprimais un dsir, vous vous em-pressiez de le satisfaire si j'avais un ennui, vous vous offriez - le partager. Vous tiez de ces loyaux compagnons qu'une femme est trop heureuse de rencontrer dans sa vie, qui l'as-sistent dans les bons et les mauvais jours et se donnent sans rserve comme sans calcul. Je voyais tout cela, je le sentais et ne mconnaissais point-vos mrites. Lui, au contraire, qu'tait-il et quel fonds pouvais-je -

Incorrect text: Vous aviez t pour moi le meilleur, le plus dvou et le plus fidle des amis vous n'aviez qu'une pense, mon bonheur qu'un but, notre union.
The corrected text is:
prediction.sentence:
You were for me the best, the most devoted and the most faithful of friends. You had one thought, my happiness, our union.

Note: You can only correct text that is in the same paragraph as the one you selected to correct.

Vous aviez t pour moi le meilleur, le plus dvou et le plus fidle des amis vous n'aviez qu'une pense
prediction.region:
"C'est ici que je l'ai besoin de votre pardon, Ludovic, d'un pardon absolu et gnreux. Par ce pardon, je reviendrai donc, avec mpris, et je te mets  l'amour tout le monde, j'ai trop longtemps voulu et avoir le soutien de toute personne. J'tais entirement contente de ce que vous me dtendraiez, et ne voyais-je pas trop ce qu'elle pouvait s'il restait un seul problme dans vos yeux. Vous l'aviez fait avec le sourire et la flicitation qui vous apportaient tous les ans, sans se laisser avoir parce qu'il s'agissait ici des faits, du travail et du courage, -la vie et l'honneur, c'est la seule chose qui m'avait tout-puissante et la plus sre. -Cet homme, en venant chez moi, avait obi  un caprice probablement il ne reviendrait plus. Et si il revenait, quoi de plus ais que de le remettre  sa place et de faire justice de ses airs cavaliers? Et s'il revenait, quoi de plus ais que de le remettre  sa place et de faire justice de ses airs cavaliers? Il valait mieux procder sans bruit, sans clat, comme une femme peut et doit le faire, que de mettre deux hommes en prsence et jusqu'aux prises pour un si lger motif? Voil  quelles impressions je cdais sans m'en rendre bien compte, ni pntrer trop avant dans mon coeur Peut-tre, hlas! en interrogeant mieux ce coeur, aurais-je trouv le dernier mot de ces rticences qui m'ont perdue. Je fais ici la demande de pardon, et vous, Ludovic, j'ai besoin de votre pardon absolu et gnreux."

The text has been corrected for spelling and grammar; punctuation has been added for clarity; and "de" in "Qu'on peut voir dans une rue" has been replaced with "de".</s>

ocr.sentence: Jamais, c'est une justice que je me plais  vous rendre, aucun chagrin ne m'est venu de vous si j'exprimais un dsir, vous vous em-pressiez de le satisfaire si j'avais un ennui, vous vous offriez  le partager.
ocr.region: CE qu'on PEUT VOIR DANS UNE rue. 257, j'obis, tant il y avait en moi de confusion et de trouble. Il faut si. peu de chose pour arrter une confidence sur les lvres, surtout lorsqu'il s'agit de s'accuser d'un tort et de se mettre  la merci d'autrui ! On s'empare alors du premier prtexte, le plus futile, le plus spcieux on recule, on ajourne, et, dans ces ajournements mmes, -on puise des mo-tifs pour s'abstenir. C'est ce qui m'arriva, Ludovic. Avant- de vous revoir, j'tais rsolue  tout vous dire, et quand je vous revis la confiance me manqua. Il n'y eut l-dedans ni raisonnement, ni calcul mais une force imprieuse et presque indpen-dante de ma volont. Puis je me payais de dfaites. Pourquoi troubler votre scurit et veiller vos soupons? La chose en valait-elle la peine? Cet homme, en venant chez moi, avait obi  un caprice probablement il n'y reviendrait plus. Et s'il revenait, quoi de plus ais que de le remettre  sa place et de faire justice de ses airs cavaliers ? tait-il besoin d'aide pour cela et ne valait-il pas mieux procder sans bruit, sans clat, .comme une femme peut et doit le faire, que de mettre deux hommes en prsence et jusqu'aux prises pour un si lger motif? Voil  quelles impressions je cdai sans m'en rendre bien compte, ni pntrer trop avant dans mon coeur Peut-tre, hlas ! en interrogeant mieux ce coeur, aurais-je trouv le dernier mot de ces rticences. La suite ne l'a que trop prouv j'tais dj touche, j'entrais dans cette srie de faiblesses qui m'ont perdue. C'est ici que j'ai besoin de votre pardon, Ludovic, d'un pardon absolu et gnreux. Point d'excuse possible, rien qui puisse pallier ce commen-cement de trahison. Vous aviez t pour moi le meilleur, le plus dvou et le plus fidle des amis vous n'aviez qu'une pense, mon bonheur qu'un but, notre union. Jamais, c'est une justice que je me plais  vous rendre, aucun chagrin ne m'est venu de vous si j'exprimais un dsir, vous vous em-pressiez de le satisfaire si j'avais un ennui, vous vous offriez - le partager. Vous tiez de ces loyaux compagnons qu'une femme est trop heureuse de rencontrer dans sa vie, qui l'as-sistent dans les bons et les mauvais jours et se donnent sans rserve comme sans calcul. Je voyais tout cela, je le sentais et ne mconnaissais point-vos mrites. Lui, au contraire, qu'tait-il et quel fonds pouvais-je -

Incorrect text: Je me sens dj des fourmis dans les jambes...
The corrected text is:
prediction.sentence: Je me sens dj des fourmis dans les jambes.</s>
prediction.region: Les tlphonistes dans la bataille  In two hours. Where is our post?  "j,' '.tJit,d - I know nothing. - ~ H - Thanks! And without replying he continued, addressing soldiers who were shooting a few cartridges. - It is the telephone operators. - Ah, the muffled ones! shouted the men. - Ah, the sentries! chorused the men. - Yes, the sentries, replied Rgnier furiously, and he continued to question - The telephone? - There is none, replied a voice, we are surrounded in a bunker! Covered to the waist, Rgnier started to tremble. - Goodnight, corporal Legrand, said an officer, shut this down once and for all. Close it once and for all, said a corporal, closing it. Good night, corporal. - D'accord, s'adressa Reganier, mme si bien sr, il sentait bien la chaleur dans l'atmosphre hostile. L-bas. deux soldats qui s'loignrent, sans plus tarder, mirent laisss leurs sacs et s'loignrent sur une poigne de main. - Ce n'est pas confortable dans ce monde-l, sigha le Mridional sitting in his uniform, and he complained about the lack of comfort. But even so, he did not feel bad, for it was not a big house. Soaked in sweat, he was sitting on a chair. - Allo! Corporal Legrand, said a corporal, it is you?. It is Rgnier who is on the truck. Good night. What about it?. It is the air. I do not like it. I feel that there are mosquitoes in my legs. Let's go to bed. They retired, without going to bed, with their sacks, and went in front on a small amount of hand.</s>

ocr.sentence: Al-lons, bonne nuit, caporal.
ocr.region: LES TLPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 11 - Dans deux heures. O est notre poste?  'j,' '.tJit,d - J'en sais rien. - ~ H - Merci! Et sans se rebuter il continua, s'adressant  des poilus qui tiraillaient quelques cartouches. - C'est les tlphonistes. - Ah, les embusqus! chuchotrent les hommes. - Oui, embusqus de premire ligne comme vous autres, rpondit Rgnier rageusement, et il continua  questionner - Le poste tlphonique? - Taisez-vous, souffla un sergent, nous sommes  vingt mtres des Boches! Soudain une tte surgit d'un trou et un bras lui lit signe d'approcher. - C'est nous, fit Rgnier, o est le poste? - Y en a pas, rpondit une voix, on est tasss dans un gourbi! Couch presque  plat ventre, Rgnier se raunJa dans l'exca-vation. - C'est maigre, miladious! murmura-t-il, enQn.! Accroupi, ramass sur lui-mme, 11 tablit tant bien que mal sa communication. - Allo! caporal Legrand, c'est vous?. C'est Rgnier qui est  l'appareil. Bon. a marche. Vous dites?. Ah! oui, je crois que le climat n'est pas sain, vu l'humidit. J'ai peur de prendre racine. Je me sens dj des fourmis dans les jambes. Al-lons, bonne nuit, caporal. - Dites donc, vous n'tes pas l pour faire la causette, fit brusquement un adjudant, fermez a une fois pour toutes. Le mieux pour lui tait de ne pas rpliquer, car il se sentait dans une atmosphre hostile. Les deux soldats qui partaient, sans plus tarder, mirent leuss sacs, s'loignrent sur une poigne de main. - Ce n'est pas confortable l dedans, soupira le Mridional assis en tailleur. j'ai des crampes dans tes genoux, mais ce qui me console, c'est que je ne paie pas mon loyer! La nuit s'annonait assez tranquille, fatigus par les atta. ques des jours prcdents, les Allemands paraissaient plutt inquiets qu'agressifs. Insensible et bris de fatigue. Buchard s'tait endormi. Seul Rgnier veillait et comme il n'avait personne  qui parler, 11 s'lait mis  manger un morceau de singe et vidait ce qui lql restait de pinard.

Il n'tait que neuf heures. La cloche continuait  sonner. Sans doute on s'tait aperu de son absence. Ce second coup de cloche tait pour l'appeler. Encore un effort et ses ennemis vont s'arrter, bien sr il n'oseront pas le poursuivre si prs de la maison. En tout cas, il y arrivera le premier! Le petit douard se trompait. La poursuite continuait. Mais douard tait rentr dans le jardin. Toute sa famille tait l qui l'appelait, qui le cherchait. Son pre tait sur la plate-forme du perron. Les domestiques effars couraient partout avec des lanternes. Chacun criait douard, douard ! La voix de sa soeur venait jusqu' lui. Papa ! papa ! s'cria douard, cher papa! je suis l ! Et le petit douard tombait  moiti mort de peur dans les bras de son pre. Mais il n'arrivait pas seul. Les voleurs, les gendarmes, tous ses ennemis, tous ses perscuteurs, anims sans doute, eux aussi, par leur course, avaient franchi la porte du jardin et faisaient effrontment irruption dans le salon en sonnant une fanfare clatante. Le croirait-on? mais la vrit nous oblige  le confesser la troupe des fantmes devant laquelle avait fui l'intrpide douard se composait d'un seul malfaiteur!... son petit ne, qui, en se trouvant tout  coup au milieu des lumires du salon, avait cru devoir clbrer son entre par le plus beau braiement qui ft jamais sorti de son gosier.

Sans s'en douter, douard avait fait le tour du parc au lieu d'aller tout droit par l'alle du milieu, il avait tourn sur lui-mme et tait revenu  son point de dpart. C'tait bien l la porte du jardin. Mais douard tait rentr dans le jardin. Toute sa famille tait l qui l'appelait, qui le cherchait. Son pre tait sur la plate-forme du perron. Les domestiques effars couraient partout avec des lanternes. Chacun criait douard, douard! La voix de sa soeur venait jusqu' lui. Papa! papa! s'cria douard, cher papa! je suis l! Et le petit douard tombait  moiti mort de peur dans les bras de son pre. Mais il n'arrivait pas seul. ocr.sentence: he said to Rush, thou lewd fellow, what hast thou done to this waggon that I am thus arayed therein ?
ocr.region: 277 OF FRIER RUSH. then he said to Rush, thou lew d fellow, what bast thou done to this waggon that I am thus arayed therein ? Rush answered and said sir, I have done nothing but as you commanded me. That is not, said the Priour, for I commaunded thee to take greace and grease but the wheeles and the axeltrees, and thou hast taken tarre and annointed it all over, both within and without. Why hast thou done so ? Sir said Rush, I understoode you bad me doe so. And when the Priour sawe there was no other remedie, he commanded his servants to makeready another waggon, and in the meane season, the Priour went into his chamber, and put on another babite, and came againe and mounted into the waggon and went their way, and so long they rode, that they came to their iourneyes end. And when they were alighted at their lodging, the Priour caUed for his supper, and anon every thing was made ready, and the good man of the house and the Priour sate downe to supper together, and made good cheere and then the Priour called for wine of the best, and anon he had his commandement. And when the good man of the house and the Priour had supped, Rush and bis fellowes sate downe to the rever sions that their maisters bad left, but they had no wine wherefore Rush was very sad, and ever he mused by what policie he might get some wine. And anon he called the wife of the house and said Mistresse, I pray you fill a pottle of wine for me and my fellowes, and so shee did and when that was gone, they caUed for another and then they called for the third, and so ended their

And when they were alighted at their lodging, the Priour caUed for his supper, and anon every thing was made ready, and the good man of the house and the Priour sate downe to supper together, and made good cheere and then the Priour called for wine of the best, and anon he had his commandement. And when the good man of the house and the Priour had supped, Rush and bis fellowes sate downe to the rever sions that their maisters bad left, but they had no wine wherefore Rush was very sad, and ever he mused by what policie he might get some wine. And anon he called the wife of the house and said Mistresse, I pray you fill a pottle of wine for me and my fellowes, and so shee did and when that was gone, they caUed for another and then they called for the third, and so ended their

groundtruth.region: he said to Rush, thou lewd fellow, what hast thou done to this waggon that I am thus arayed therein ? Rush answered and said sir, I have done nothing but as you commanded me. That is not, said the Priour, for I commaunded thee to take greace and grease but the wheeles and the axeltrees, and thou hast taken tarre and annointed it all over, both within and without. Why hast thou done so ? Sir said Rush, I understoode you bad me doe so. And when the Priour sawe there was no other remedie, he commanded his servants to make ready another waggon, and in the meane season, the Priour went into his chamber, and put on another habite, and came againe and mounted into the waggon and went their way, and so long they rode, that they came to their iourneyes end. And when they were alighted at their lodging, the Priour called for his supper, and anon every thing was made ready, and the good man of the house and the Priour sate downe to supper together, and made good cheere and then the Priour called for wine of the best, and anon he had his commandement. And when the good man of the house and the Priour had supped, Rush and his fellowes sate downe to the rever-sions that their maisters had left, but they had no wine wherefore Rush was very sad, and ever he mused by what policie he might get some wine. And when Frier Rush saw that they were fighting together, anon he blew out all the candles and lamps that were burning in the church, and left no manner of Hght therein whereby the one might see the other and when he had so done, be tooke his truncheon in his hand, and went into the Quier among the thickest of the Friers the which were fighting freshly without light, and there he laid so lustily about, that many of them he felled to the ground, and left them there for dead, and when he had so done, he stole his way from them, and as hee went, he found standing in the portaU of the Quier, a great olde deske, and anon hee tooke the deske betweene both his hands, and threw it over the portad into the Quier among aU the Friers, and hurt many sore, in so much that some had an arme broken, and some a legge, and other some had their noses, cleane pared from their faces, that the bloud ranne in their mouthes, and as for broken heads to the hard scalpe were no dainty, for every man had one, there scaped none free away, who had been there, should have had a goodly pastime to see the Friers creepe about the Quier, and in steede of Domine labia they cried out alas and well away. ocr.sentence: their malicious mindes and angry hearts, every man after other went privately to Frier Rush to lend them staves, in so much that there was not a Frier in the place but he had one, and they never went without their staves under their habite, and the one knew not that the other had any, they kept them so secretly.
ocr.region: OF FRIER RUSH. 273 filling their malicious mindes and angry hearts, every man after other went privately to Frier Rush to lend them staves, in so much that there was not a Frier in the place but he had one, and they never went without their staves under their habite, and the one knew not that the other had any, they kept them so secretly. And when Frier Rush had delivered aH his staves, he was right glad in his heart, for he knew right well there should be a great fray among them, either one time or other. So it fortuned afterward, as it is a common cus-tome among religious people at an high feast, to keepe solemne service, and every man to be at Mattens at midnight, and so upon a good night, all the whole Covent assembled together in the Quier, and were ready to begin Mattens, they taried for nothing but for the comming of the Priour. Then anon the Priour came into the Quier, and sate him downe in his place, and as he looked about him, he espied that the Subpriour was there present, and with that his heart began to grudge of the olde anger that was fallen betweene them two, and he thought in his minde that he could never be revenged in a better time, and sodainly he rose out of his place, and went to the Subpriour, and with his fist he gave him a good buffet, and the Subpriour which was moved with the stroke, started unto the Priour and gave him another buffet, and with that they went freshly together by the eares, and when the other Friers saw that, every man rose out of their places, and drew out their Truncheons, and together they went who VOL. I.

And when Frier Rush had delivered all his staves, he was right glad in his heart, for he knew right well there should be a great fray among them, either one time or other. So it fortuned afterward, as it is a common cus-tome among religious people at an high feast, to keepe solemne service, and every man to be at Mattens at midnight, and so upon a good night, all the whole Covent assembled together in the Quier, and were ready to begin Mattens, they taried for nothing but for the comming of the Priour. Then anon the Priour came into the Quier, and sate him downe in his place, and as he looked about him, he espied that the Subpriour was there present, and with that his heart began to grudge of the olde anger that was fallen betweene them two, and he thought in his minde that he could never be revenged in a better time, and sodainly he rose out of his place, and went to the Subpriour, and with his fist he gave him a good buffet, and the Subpriour which was moved with the stroke, started unto the Priour and gave him another buffet, and with that they went freshly together by the eares, and when the other Friers saw that, every man rose out of their places, and drew out their Truncheons, and together they went who

ocr.region: OF FRYER BACON. 243 George, who fought with the dragon, and killed it Vandermast following his example raysed up Perseus, who fought also with his sea-monster, and kdled it, so were they both released from their danger. They being not contented with this tryall of their skill, went further in their coniurations, and raised up two spirits, each of them one. Bungye charged his spirit for to assist him with the greatest power hee had, that by it he might be able to overcome Vandermast. The Devdl told him he would, if that he from his left arme would give him but three drops of blood but if that he did deny him that, then should Vandermast have power over him to doe what he would the Hke told Vandermasts Devill to him to this demand of the spirits, they both agreed, thinking for to overcome each other but the Devill overthrew them both. They having given the Devill this bloud, as is before spoken of, they both fell againe to their coniurations first, Bungye did rayse Achilles with bis Greekes, who marched about Vandermast and threatned him. Then Vandermast raised Hector with his Troians, who defended him from AchiUes and the Greekes. Then began there a great batteU between the Greekes and Troians, which continued a good space at last Hector was slaine, and the Troians fled. Then did follow a great tempest, with thundring and lightning, so that the two coniurers wished that they had been away. But wishes were in vaine for now the time was come, that the Devill would be paid for the knowledge that he had

The Devdl told him he would, if that he from his left arme would give him but three drops of blood but if that he did deny him that, then should Vandermast have power over him to doe what he would the Hke told Vandermasts Devill to him to this demand of the spirits, they both agreed, thinking for to overcome each other but the Devill overthrew them both. They having given the Devill this bloud, as is before spoken of, they both fell againe to their coniurations first, Bungye did rayse Achilles with bis Greekes, who marched about Vandermast and threatned him. Then Vandermast raised Hector with his Troians, who defended him from AchiUes and the Greekes. Then began there a great batteU between the Greekes and Troians, which continued a good space at last Hector was slaine, and the Troians fled. Then did follow a great tempest, with thundring and lightning, so that the two coniurers wished that they had been away. But wishes were in vain for now the time was come, that the Devill would be paid for the knowledge that he had

ocr.region: 264 A PLEASANT HISTORIE good and well disposed people, they spent in unthrifti nesse and rybauldry. And when the great prince of devils which are the patrones of aU vices understood of the great misrule and rile living of these religious men consulted to keepe them still in that state, and worse if it might be. And these be the names of the devils. Belphegor who was Prince of Gluttony, Asmodeus Prince of Lechery, and Belzebub Prince of Envie, with many other divels assembled together, which reioyced for the misorder of these religious men. And as they were all assembled together with one accord they chose a divell to goe and dwell among these religious men, for to maintaine them the longer in their ungracious living, which divell was put in rayment Hke an earthly crea ture, and went to a religious house, and there he stood at the gate a certaine space all alone with an heavie countenance. Then within a while after the Priour came unto the gate and espied Rush the young man standing there ad alone. Anon he said unto him, what dost thou here, and what wouldest thou have. The young man with great reverence answered and said Sir, I am a poore young man, and am out of service, and faine would have a maister. And sir if it please you to have me, I shall doe you diligent service, and shaddoe so well that you and all your brethren and covent shall be glad of me, for I shall keepe so weU your secrets, that I trust to obtaine at all times your good love and favour, and all theirs also. And when the Priour had heard his words, he was
